V.ii.2.A.3.e
.
Definition:
Satisfactory Evidence
Satisfactory evidence
generally means evidence that is credible.
It is proper to
consider internal consistency and plausibility in determining whether evidence is credible, and
regard statements that contradict other evidence of record as unsatisfactory.
Reference
:Â  For more information on determining whether evidence is
credible, see
M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, 1.A.2.b
, and
Caluza v. Brown
, 7 Vet.App. 508 (1995).
title: M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, Chapter 2, Section A - Direct Service Connection (SC) and Service Incurrence of an Injury
citation: Part V, Subpart ii, Chapter 2, Section A
